conclusion: An ideal gas changes from state A to state B, and then to state C. The temperature at state A is 27°C.
The p-V diagram shows the x-axis as volume in cubic meters (m³) and the y-axis as pressure in pascals (Pa).
At state A, the pressure is 3 × 10^5 Pa and the volume is 1 × 10^-3 m³.
At state B, the pressure is 1 × 10^5 Pa and the volume is 1 × 10^-3 m³.
At state C, the pressure is 1 × 10^5 Pa and the volume is 3 × 10^-3 m³.
The temperature at state A is 27°C.

premise: From state A to state B, the volume doesn't change; only the pressure changes.
conclusion: If volume is constant, the relationship between pressure and temperature follows P ∝ T.

premise: P₁/T₁ = P₂/T₂ and T₁ = 300 K, P₁ = 3 × 10^5 Pa, P₂ = 1 × 10^5 Pa.
Re-evaluation of the ideal gas law and process.
